standfirst.value: Where do Americans get their news? Who is the typical consumer of news? And how many people can really be counted as being in partisan “echo chambers”? We had these questions in mind when putting together the four interactive charts on this page, which are basically reproduced from two Science Advances articles published in 2020 and 2022 (read the originals here and here). The underlying datasets are derived from large panels (50-100k) of individuals who agreed to having their desktop internet browsing and TV viewing behavior passively tracked.

In the first figure, we tally the average time spent watching news and non-news on TV; online content is analyzed in terms of a larger set of categories, including social media platforms and hyper-partisan and fake sites. The clearest pattern is that older Americans spend much more time on news than younger Americans. Moreover, across all age groups, but especially for older Americans, TV news dominates online news articles in terms of total time spent. Put simply, when we talk about traditional news audiences in the US, we are primarily talking about older people watching TV.

partisanship.title: Partisanship
partisanship.description: Lenient means that websites more partisan than TheGuardian.com (FoxNews.com) are counted as left (right), and CNN is counted as left-leaning. The strict definition means partisan content bounds are Slate.com (Breitbart.com) on the left (right)

captions.value: Minutes per person per day spent with news and other categories of content on TV and desktop browsing.

copy.value: The 2022 article was inspired by popular and academic discussion of “echo chambers,” or the idea that social media has led people to be exposed to overwhelmingly partisan and like-minded news content. To gauge the scale of the echo chamber problem, this figure asks, thow many people have a news diet that is made of majority highly partisan sources? The design of the figure is somewhat unique because we present results corresponding to multiple definitions of majority, 50% and 75%. You can also toggle the definition of “highly partisan” with the lenient/stringent button.

While most people think of echo chambers in terms of online information, we find that cable TV, especially Fox News, is more responsible for the partisan segregation in news audiences than any combination of far-right or far-left sites circulating the internet. For example, between 10%-15% of Americans aged 55 and older get the majority of their news from Fox News, depending on the month and the definition chosen. Meanwhile, the online echo chambers never eclipse even 5% of US internet users, for any month and any definition.

captions.value: The monthly percent of Americans experiencing partisan segregation via TV or Web news. Bounds represent a range of percentages—from 50 to 75—of individual-level news diets that must be partisan for partisan segregation.

copy.value: In this map, the size of each semi-circle represents the number of people with segregated news diets in that state. You can click on a state for more information, including the most watched news programs & domains a state-level time series of audience segregation.

When we break the TV audience segregation measurements down by state, we see surprisingly minimal geographic variation. In the “lenient” view, where CNN is counted as left-wing partisan, the Fox News echo chamber still dominates that of the left in nearly every state, with York and California being notable exceptions. If, however, we take the “stringent” definition of partisan, and count only MSNBC as leftwing partisan, then Fox News easily dominates in every single state (though not Washington DC).
Toggling to the web view, we can see that left-wing audience segregation is relatively bigger online.

captions.value: Each state is represented in terms of the total number of residents whose news diets are dominated by right-wing and left-wing partisan sources. The shades of red and blue indicate the percentage of residents. Click on a state for more info.
State-level timeline of echo chamber size as % of total population
We define audience size on the program and domain level as our estimate of the number of people spent at least one hour in a given month

copy.value: In the last figure we introduce one more concept, the news consumption archetype. Rather than assume there to be a singularly typical news viewer, we surface 8 archetypes of news consumption by clustering panelists with similarly distributed news diets. We can then measure the size of each archetype as well as individual movement from one type of behavior to another by assigning panelists each month to the cluster/archetype to which their news diet is most similar. [read the paper for more details]

It turns out that each archetypal news diet is dominated by a single category of news. In the figure, each archetype is represented by a node whose size corresponds to the number of people exhibiting that archetypal behavior and whose label is the dominant category. We also include a special archetype called “no news”, which represents all of the panelists that spend 30 minutes or less on news in a given month.

Hard broadcast news is the largest archetype, by millions of viewers, but it’s rapidly shrinking. The arrows between nodes represent “net flow” between archetypes, a metric of pairwise inflow minus outflow designed to capture viewership migrations. The universe of active.

captions.value: Television news consumption archetypes are each labeled according to the category of news most prominently consumed within the archetype, along with a large ninth group of people who are exposed to less than 30 min of news in a month, calculated independently in each month over the 4 years of analysis. The figure represents the direction and magnitude of turnover between each pair of archetypes. For example, if—over a given period of time—1M individuals moved from archetype A to archetype B, and over the same period of time 4M individuals did the reverse and moved from archetype B to A, then the net flow over that time period would be 3M from B to A.
